data.text: Contents
Introduction

Ensuring hospitals are clean and safe is an essential component in the provision of effective healthcare. A clean and tidy environment is an outward manifestation of the health of the NHS and provides the right setting for effective patient care. It is fundamental in assisting patients to recover and providing assurance to patients they  are  being  cared  for  in  a  safe/clean  environment,  contributing  to  the minimisation of risk towards Healthcare associated infections. The trust recognises that wider environmental issues also contribute to this and all staff are responsible for helping to maintain a positive impression of the hospitals sites.

Cleanliness and infection control are closely linked in the public mind, however there  are  important  distinctions  to  be  made;  whilst  cleanliness  contributes  to infection  control,  preventing  infections  requires  more  than  simple  cleanliness. Working  alongside  clinical  directorates  in  ensuring  this  cleaning  framework  is adhered to by all staff ensures the highest of standards are being met at all times.

There are numerous publications to assist the trust in ensuring that their cleaning programmes are properly focussed, effectively resourced and that they consistently deliver high quality services that are well regarded by patients. These include the latest National Specifications of Cleanliness in the NHS.

The cleaning of premises within the  trust is carried out by teams of Domestic Assistants. The focus on improving hospital cleanliness and reducing healthcare associated infection has never been more topical and it is important to recognise the critical role that domestic staff plays in ensuring public confidence in the overall cleanliness of the hospital environment. This is recognised and supported by EFM management and clinical directorates.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Set  out  the  approach  in  providing  clear  direction  in  respect  of  cleaning standards and operations to deliver a clean and safe environment for staff, patients /service users and visitors and give assurance that the environment is being  cleaned  to  meet  specific  standards.  This  policy  should  be  read  in conjunction with the Trust's Strategic Cleaning Plan.

This Cleaning Policy supported by the Strategic Cleaning Plan will enable the Trust to comply with all relevant legislation and guidance, in particular the Health and Social Care Act (2008) and the latest National Specifications for Cleanliness in the NHS, or relevant national guidance.

The cleaning policy embraces all cleaning activity carried out within the remit of the Domestic Services Department across the trust. This includes all general scheduled and reactive cleaning activities undertaken by the Trust's Domestic Services Department, as well as those traditionally undertaken by the Estates Department (i.e. wall washing, ceiling vents) , cleaning duties undertaken by nursing staff (i.e. patient related equipment) and cleaning duties undertaken by catering staff (i.e. kitchen areas and catering equipment).

A clean hospital environment is paramount to all staff and patients in preventing /controlling the spread of healthcare associated infections (HCAIs) as well as providing a safe and comfortable environment to aid patient care and recovery.

There are many factors that influence the overall impression of the hospital presented by the organisation. It is recognised within the Trust that as buildings becomes older, the cleaning often becomes more of a challenge. Therefore, the trust continually reviews and develops Service Level Agreements to ensure standards are maintained, and recognises its responsibilities to wider environmental issues.
It is also recognised that all employees have a responsibility to care for their work environment and using this policy in conjunction with the Strategic Cleaning plan we aim to:

Provide direction in maintaining and improving cleanliness standards across all hospital sites and premises, ensuring a clean, comfortable and safe environment for patients, clients, visitors, staff and members of the general
public
Definitions

table_items.text: A process which physically removes organic matter but does not necessarily destroy micro-organisms. It is carried out using detergent to help remove the debris.

The removal of micro-organisms to a safe and acceptable level, carried out using either heat or a disinfectant chemical. Disinfection / decontamination cannot take place on an unclean surface as organic matter will interfere with the disinfectant. Therefore all surfaces must be cleaned before they can be disinfected.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Infection Prevention and Control Group
The Infection Prevention and Control Group are responsible for:
Reviewing and supporting the implementing the Strategic Cleaning Plan and Cleaning Policy;
Assisting in ensuring the Trust is compliant with decontamination guidance and Prevention and Control of Healthcare Associated Infections and related guidance;
Giving assurance that local decontamination practices meet with national standards; reviewing cleaning standards audit results and cleaning operational procedures.
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive is responsible for:
Ensuring that there are effective arrangements for infection control throughout the Trust;
Ensuring sufficient resources to comply with this policy
Director of infection & Prevention Control-DIPC
The Director of Infection and Prevention has the executive role for Infection Prevention and Control with the responsibilities to:
Lead an Infection Control Team to monitor the achieved cleanliness standard in the hospital and to liaise closely with the Domestic Department on all cleanliness related matters.
Ensure that there is a Trust committee for Infection and Prevention Control which is representative of the service directorate and Infection Prevention and Control team
Oversee local control of infection policies and their implementation.
Report control of infection matters directly to the Chief Executive and the Board
Challenge inappropriate clinical hygiene practice as well as anti-biotic prescribing hygiene practice.
Assess the impact and all National and Local policies on infection and make recommendation for change.
Implement the Code of Practice on Infection Prevention and Control within the Trust and advise the Board on any issues related to compliance against the code
Ensure control of infection activities are reported to the appropriate Trust wide groups, those include, Trust Clinical Governance and Risk Group, Trust Health and Safety Committee
Produce an annual report to the Board on the state of health care associated infection in the Trust.
Chief Estates & Facilities Officer
The Chief Estates & Facilities Officer is responsible for:
Ensuring hospital cleanliness is high on the corporate agenda;
Ensure a cleaning policy and strategy is in place and significant changes to legislation and site operations are communicated for policy review;
Ensure the Trust complies with National Requirements with respect to domestic services.
Estates & Facilities Site Manager/Group Soft Services Lead
The Estates & Facilities Site Manager is responsible for:
Ensuring Hospital cleanliness is high on the corporate agenda;
Ensuring that premises are fit for purpose, maintained and clean;
Providing professional leadership for cleaning services;
Providing the operational cleaning framework within which the Domestic teams operate.
Chief Nurse
The Chief Nurse is responsible for:
Ensuring that nursing practice is in line with Trust policies and objectives;
Ensuring that job descriptions and appraisals are in place and reflect the importance of infection control;
Ensuring that nurses and midwives are trained effectively in key techniques.
Associate Director of Operations and Clinical Directors
The Associate Director of Operations and Clinical Directors are responsible for:

Ensuring effective management practice and response is maintained in relation to infection control to effectively contribute to a reduction in hospital acquired infection and achievement of the MRSA and Clostridium difficile trajectories;
Ensuring all staff in their areas are aware of and understand this Policy that it is embedded into practice locally and within their areas of responsibility;
Investigating failures to comply with this Policy and ensure corrective action is taken to prevent a recurrence.
Associate Directors of Nursing/ Heads of Nursing
The Associate Directors of Nursing are responsible for:

Supporting the performance and delivery of access targets within an environment that does not compromise clinical practice but maximises the opportunity to ensure delivery with infection free environments;
Supporting discussion at speciality and Directorate meetings to make sure that there is a routine review of infection data and take action to maintain compliance with the Directorates;
Ensuring that all nurses and midwives are suitable trained and that job descriptions, objectives and appraisals reflect the importance of infection control;
Holding Lead Nurses to account for nursing/midwifery practice in their area;
Matrons
The Matrons are responsible for:
Delivering a safe and clean care environment with direct responsibility for Ensuring that cleanliness standards are maintained throughout the shift;
Ensuring all staff are familiar with escalation procedures for additional cleaning;
Ensuring that all patient equipment is cleaned between patient use to standards as outlined within the National Specification for Cleanliness, April 2007;
Ensuring that correct documentation is completed to evidence that cleaning practices have been undertaken;
Working closely with the ward/departmental domestic staff.
Nursing & Housekeeping staff
Nurses and Ward Housekeepers are responsible for:
Delivering a safe and clean care environment with direct responsibility for Ensuring that cleanliness standards are maintained throughout the shift;
Ensuring familiarisation with escalation procedures for additional cleaning;
Ensuring that all patient equipment is cleaned between patient use to standards as outlined within the National Specification for Cleanliness, April 2007;
Ensuring that correct documentation is completed to evidence that cleaning practices have been undertaken;
Working closely with the ward/departmental domestic staff.
Infection Prevention Team
The Infection Prevention Team will work closely with the Domestic Services department to:
Provide technical advice on specialised cleaning agents, equipment and methodology of cleaning;
Provide advice and be consulted on all matters related to cleaning contracts and cleaning frequencies; provide appropriate mandatory infection prevention training to all staff;
Participate in working groups in relation to all aspects of cleanliness
Contribute to inspections such as Patient-Led Assessments of the Care Environment (PLACE).
EFM Business Development Unit
The EFM Business Development Unit are responsible for:
Delivering and ensuring compliance against the cleaning auditing programme;
Conduct unannounced joint managerial audits in line with Trust policy ensuring all relevant representatives from the Domestic Services Department and ward areas are present.

Providing audit results and actions, and weekly and monthly cleaning reports to senior management (Chief Executive, Chief Estates & Facilities Officer and Site Manager, Director of Nursing, ANDs, ADO's, Matrons and Sisters);
Liaise with Domestic Management Team regarding any concerns, queries or enquires that fall within the Domestic Service remit and Escalating issues related to cleanliness to Senior Management.
Domestic Services Management Team
The Domestic Services Management Team is responsible for:
Managing the day to day service delivery of the Domestic cleaning service within the Trust. Responsibilities include:
Setting standards;
Maintain and adhere to Agreed NHS National Specification of Cleaning standards.
Selecting equipment, products, methods of cleaning;
Control departmental budgets, stock management, labour management and other financial aspects of the Domestic Services department.
Ensure all Domestic staff are trained and correct competencies are in place to evidence this.
Ensure all incidents have been reviewed and risks managed and report to Site Manager and Chief Estates & Facilities Officer trends identified from analysis of incidents accordingly.
Establishment and ongoing review of Strategic Cleaning Plan and Cleaning Policy;
Reporting to management and infection control on cleaning standards.
Maintain key working relationships with Modern Matrons, Estates and Facilities managers (EFM) Infection Control Team, Facilities Training Manager and other service users.
Domestic Supervisors
The Domestic Supervisors are responsible for:
Working with the ward/department and undertaking cleaning monitoring of the ward/department in accordance with the national specifications;

Assisting the Domestic management team in leading Domestic Staff and ensuring that the day to day cleaning duties are completed in accordance with the service specifications determined within the ward/department.
Arrange, plan and deliver Domestic Staff training and refresher training as well as assisting in induction training and carrying out train the trainer duties where appropriate.
Monitor Domestic Staff to ensure the successful implementation of the Agreed NHS National Specification of Cleanliness
Monitor the Incident Reporting system, ensuring all incidents are investigated and reviewed in the timeframe stated and reporting incidents to the Domestic Services Manager where needed.
Ensure all local procedures relevant to Domestic Staff duties are kept up to date including updates from Health and Safety and report any changes to Domestic Services Manager.
Ensure all policies and procedures are being adhered to by Domestic Staff throughout the trust including local procedures of duties in place.

Inspect and monitor the use of equipment to ensure appropriate use and proper storage of equipment and machineries to avoid theft and misuse. The supervisor is responsible for all items of equipment issued to the team and accountable for those assets being maintained in a safe, clean and serviceable condition in line with the manufacturer's guide-lines
Manage daily labour input and allocate staff to appropriate areas/wards as assigned on establishment post and ensure that all areas are fully staffed.
Domestic Staff/Team
The Domestic staff are responsible for:
To maintain the cleanliness of the ward / department environment in accordance with the cleaning SLAs and National Cleanliness Standards ;
Report any repairs/concerns/incidents that could be detrimental to the Domestic Service delivery;
Adhere to the policies and procedures relating to domestic services;
Contribute to the reduction of healthcare acquired infections by ensuring high standards of infection control practice.
Maintaining cleaning equipment to Trust standard following the local procedure in place.
Actively participate in ward/department audits in their own working environment as requested by their supervisors.
Attend all mandatory training provided and ensure that all training is kept up to date and compliant.
Domestic Bed Cleaning/Teletracking Team
The Domestic Bed Cleaning/Teletracking Team are responsible for:
Ensure that cleanliness is maintained of the bed and bed space following a patient discharge in line with national cleaning standards and in accordance with average response and cleaning targets;
Support the domestic services team with Ad hoc cleaning requests, daily cleaning tasks, and cleaning of public areas between bed cleaning requests;
Report any repairs/concerns/incidents that could be detrimental to the Domestic Service delivery;
Adhere to the policies and procedures relating to domestic services;
Contribute to the reduction of healthcare acquired infections by ensuring high standards of infection control practice.
Maintaining cleaning equipment to Trust standard following the local procedure in place.
Attend all mandatory training provided and ensure that all training is kept up to date and compliant.
Catering Staff/Team
The Catering Staff are responsible for:

Working with the ward/department and undertaking cleaning duties involving ward/zonal kitchen areas, beverage rooms and all kitchen equipment in accordance with the service specifications determined within the ward/department;
Where required, to work in line with domestic responsibilities.
All catering responsibilities are applicable to in-house and outsourced catering services.
All staff
All staff have a duty to:
Contribute towards the cleanliness of the Trust by ensuring all litter and waste is placed in appropriate receptacles.
Report any concerns relating to cleanliness to the Domestic Services Department or Facilities Helpdesk immediately.
Provide appropriate feedback to Domestic Management Team to enable the best service delivery from the Domestic Services Department.
Cleaning is everyone's responsibility and staff should ensure their work does not have a negative impact on the work of any other staff.
Cleaning Procedure
Cleaning Records

5.1.1 Cleaning records have been developed and implemented whereby all cleaning information relating to a ward/department are centrally located, clearly identifying cleaning responsibilities for domestic, nursing and estates
5.1.2 The Cleaning records should be easily accessible to all staff working in a ward/department.

5.1.3 Results from Managerial and Technical cleaning audits and subsequent action plans are emailed to the ward/department senior lead by the EFM Business Development Unit to monitor progress and highlight any outstanding issues.
5.1.4 Checklists should be used in line with the Cleaning and Decontamination policies.
Procedure of Cleaning
5.2.1 All clinical areas must be cleaned daily using an approved product.

5.2.2 Infected areas such as isolation rooms as identified by Infection Prevention and reported to the domestic services team must been cleaned daily using an approved product and a Terminal Clean completed upon the patient's discharge.

5.2.3 Appropriate cleaning of each patient bed space should occur on a daily basis and between every patient admission in accordance with guidelines and methods of cleaning should be followed in accordance with the Trust's Isolation Policy, including routine cleaning, standard isolation cleaning and terminal cleaning of the bed and bed space between admission.
5.2.4 The Trust pledges that patients will be admitted to both a bed and bed space thoroughly cleaned after the last patient. It is unacceptable to admit a patient into a
bed space until this has been completed. Systems are in place to indicate that a bed space and equipment have been cleaned and is appropriate for the admission.
5.2.5 Ward Sisters or their deputy will undertake a risk assessment in the event of internal patient transfers within the ward environment due to clinical necessity.
5.2.6 The cleaning agent approved to be used is Diffx (non-chlorine disinfectant product), and must be used in accordance with the training provided by the supplier.
5.2.7 The national colour coding scheme is adopted within the Trust in accordance with the National Specification of Cleanliness.

5.2.8 Mattresses should be cleaned between each patient following discharge as outlined in the Mattress Policy. Nursing staff are responsible for checking the integrity of the mattress cover and foam core during this process. Nursing staff must complete the procedures regarding cleaning and returning mattresses as outlined in the Mattress policy.
Hydrogen Peroxide Vapour (HPV) Decontamination Technology

5.3.1 This method of decontamination, also known as ‘fogging', is ideally suited for use in healthcare facilities due to its rapid, flexible and 'residue-free' nature. HPV has extensively proven biological efficacy against a wide range of environmentally associated pathogens whilst being safe for the surrounding environment. This procedure must only be carried out by trained domestic staff in accordance the HPV policy.

5.3.2 HPV decontamination can be applied safely even where expensive electronic equipment is situated. HPV decontamination has proven material compatibility so all equipment can be safely decontaminated in situ with no detrimental effect on performance or aesthetics. This is critical during the "deep clean" process where these areas have traditionally been hard to reach or where the decontaminants are incompatible with sensitive electronics, particularly chlorine-based products (including bleach). This process is also used following clearance from Infection Prevention Team over Clostridium difficile (C diff) patients.
Standard for Curtain Changing

5.4.1 In accordance with the National Specifications for Cleanliness in the NHS, curtains/blinds should be visibly clean with no blood and body substances, dust, dirt, debris, stains or spillages. The trust uses disposable curtains as approved by infection prevention.
5.4.2 Curtains must be changed immediately when visibly soiled and during a terminal clean if required, or as part of the Curtain Change Programme as outlined below:

table_items.text: Significant Risks and Low Risk Areas

data.text: 5.4.3 Curtain changes are recorded on a Log held in the Domestic Supervisors office and the change is indicated as either an ad hoc or a programmed change.

5.4.4 The Curtain change programme can be carried out by a contractor or the domestic services team, although domestic services maintain the overall responsibility of ensuring curtains are clean, hung correctly, and dated as required.
Standard for Radiator Cleaning
5.5.1 Radiator cleaning is identified by ward staff / Domestic Supervisors and staff within the affected area. Once identified ward Domestics are to clean as appropriate.
5.5.2 Radiators must be cleaned following the discharge of a patient who has been symptomatic and confirmed to have C diff or norovirus.
5.5.3 Estates & Facilities will remove the radiator covers for the retained estate – request to be placed via the Facilities Helpdesk.
5.5.4 Nurses should request radiator cleaning by contacting the Facilities Helpdesk.
5.5.5 A ward based radiator cleaning programme is carried out throughout the year as part of the Radiator Cleaning Programme as outlined below:
Steam Cleaning
5.6.1 Steam cleaning is becoming an essential part of our cleaning systems and methods.
5.6.2 The Trust uses an environmentally friendly, easy to use system that is beneficial in helping to lower health care associated infections.

5.6.3 It is a dry steam system that can instantly clean and dry surfaces without leaving any unhygienic residue. Each ward is provided with a steam cleaner that both nursing and domestic staff can use.
5.6.4 Steam cleaning will enable the Trust to achieve higher standards of cleanliness and hygiene.
Cleaning Schedules

5.7.1 Cleaning Services are provided in house across the trust. The cleaning service has been developed in accordance with National Specifications for Cleanliness in the NHS. Each functional area is assigned one of four risk categories according to its functionality:

table_items.text: Unit, ITU/HDU, A&E, Neonatal, Theatres, and other areas where invasive procedures are performed.
Wards, Sterile Services, Pharmacy, Public toilets and thoroughfares.
Administrative areas, non-sterile supply areas, healthcare records.

data.text: 5.7.2 The Trust has a terminal clean resource operating an ‘out of hour' service. Terminal cleans are operating on a 24/7 basis. If additional support is required, then the domestic services department has a mechanism in place to divert other resources from their current task. All terminal cleans should be requested directly by the ward/department using the approved designated system. The Domestic Services department is contactable through this process.

5.7.3 Service level agreements are produced for each ward and clinical department. They identify all cleaning requirements for these areas detailing the risk categories for each cleaning task. They include cleaning frequencies and standards to be achieved. They are monitored by audits and inspections which are at agreed frequencies depending on the risk level as identified.
5.7.4 Domestic assistance is available 24/7 via following the site specific processes.
Cleaning Responsibilities

5.8.1 Reference is made to the fact that not all parts of healthcare facilities and equipment are always cleaned by the Domestic Services department. Cleaning may involve the Domestic, Nurse, Housekeeper, HCA, Estates department and it is important that there is clear distinction around who is responsible for which component, including the frequency of cleaning & method of cleaning.
5.8.2 Cleaning responsibilities are established for all cleaning tasks that Domestic and Nursing staff are required to complete.
5.8.3 Nursing cleaning responsibilities are determined within the Decontamination Policy.

5.8.4 Domestic Services works closely with the Infection Prevention Team in ensuring the cleaning standards throughout the trust are maintained. Regular ward rounds take place with Domestic management and the Director of Infection Prevention and control (DIPC) to review these standards
Good Practice Measures for Infection Prevention

5.9.1 The Domestic Services Department works in close partnership with the Infection Prevention Team and are involved in the development and implementation of local standard precaution protocols and procedures following any outbreak of infection.
5.9.2 A colour coding system is used to prevent cross contamination and forms part of the cleaning services induction programme and relates to all cleaning equipment and cloths.
5.9.3 The cleaning schedules, frequency of cleaning and cleaning responsibilities used by the Trust are all agreed with the Infection Prevention Team, Ward Sisters or Departmental Managers.
5.9.4 All Cleaning staff including Managers and Supervisors are trained in the use of appropriate infection prevention procedures.

5.9.5 In the event of an outbreak there are defined protocols in place within the Trust policy for the management of Infection Control Outbreaks (which can be found on the Staff intranet). These protocols clearly defines the individual responsibilities of staff during this time to provide clear lines of communication between cleaning services, ward managers and the Infection Prevention Team.
5.9.6 The DIPC will chair an Outbreak Meeting, to manage these controls and will provide the Domestic Manager with instructions to disseminate to the Domestic staffs,
Domestic Management Team and other relevant management teams of the affected areas in regards to additional cleaning frequencies and timeframes of the deep clean procedure.

5.9.7 A request will be made for an increase in frequency of cleaning of frequently touched areas that will be approved by infection prevention. Any members of staff receiving antibiotic treatment must refrain from working in these areas. Members of staff must wear scrubs at all times in accordance to policy and guidelines. Strict hand hygiene and PPE guidance is to be followed at all times.

5.9.8 Operational procedures must be in place and shared accordingly for the delivery of a planned approach for control measures during a national viral outbreak, such as COVID-19. These measures should incorporate maintenance of cleanliness standards during the viral outbreak situation, reduce the incidence of healthcare associated infection; and minimise the risk to patients and staff by identifying and containing/controlling the spread of infection in a viral outbreak situation by implementing strategic operational services in addition to daily services.

5.9.9 Where patients have been identified as suspected infectious or confirmed infectious of the viral outbreak, cleaning procedures should be approached as compliant with Standard Isolation Cleaning or Terminal Cleaning procedures.

5.9.10 Appropriate cleaning of each patient bed and bed space should occur on a daily basis and between every patient admission in accordance with guidelines, using the appropriate PPE as per national guidance. A breakdown of which methods of cleaning should be followed in accordance with the Trust's Isolation Policy.
Bodily Fluids
5.10.1 A spillage is contamination of the environment by blood, body fluid or excreta.

5.10.2 All spillages of blood or body fluid should be considered as potentially infectious. The person witnessing the event should deal with spillages immediately. This will reduce the risk of exposure to infectious agents or further contamination.

5.10.3 Infectious agents can survive for long periods of time in spillages. It is essential, therefore, that all clinical and domestic staff receives training in spillage management and, where possible, appropriate equipment is readily available.

5.10.4 For the effective management of spillages in healthcare facilities, surfaces such as walls, floors and upholstery should be smooth, continuous and moisture repellent. Carpets should be avoided in all areas where patients are managed. All surfaces should be able to withstand frequent cleaning including cleaning with chlorine-based agents.
5.10.5 A non-chlorine releasing agent such as Diffx is recommended for the safe disinfection of all spillages including urine and vomit, prior to cleaning.
5.10.6 Spillages of blood and bodily fluids in clinical areas must be decontaminated promptly - this is usually undertaken by the nursing team caring for the patient.
5.10.7 However, trained domestic staff can undertake this task in non-clinical areas, and external areas of the hospital, where the clinical responsibility cannot be located.
5.10.8 Chemical spills must be managed according to COSHH/Risk assessment in place for the product concerned.
Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH)
5.11.1 The trust has issued a COSHH policy and associated procedures as a means of achieving a safe environment in respect of the storage, use, handling and disposal of hazardous substances.

5.11.2 The Domestic Services Management team are responsible for ensuring that all chemicals used for cleaning purposes have a current Safety Data Sheet logged in the department and reference to these must be kept in the individual ward cleaning folders. Risk Assessment Forms for all new products must be completed and copies issued to the H&S Manager.
5.11.3 The Domestic Services Management team must ensure compliance with the Trust's COSHH Policy including providing any necessary training for the safe use and storage of chemicals.

5.11.4 COSHH training is part of the domestic department's health and safety awareness programme and regular health and safety events throughout the year are supported by Domestic Services Management team.

5.11.5 A training record is kept within the Domestics Department of all staff that have received generic COSHH awareness training, which should be renewed annually. Further records are kept for identified staff who deal with specific products in specific areas and require additional training.
5.11.6 Only staff who have received COSHH awareness or specific COSHH training are permitted to use those products.
Public Area

5.12.1 A dedicated team is resourced to clean public corridor floors, waste bins, lifts and stairs, public toilets external entrances and external stairwells. This includes reactive cleaning of these areas, and support from the Grounds & Gardens team and contracted providers for clearing internal and external entrances and pathways.
5.12.2 During foul weather conditions, additional cleaning of entrances is undertaken to reduce the risk of slips and trips attributable to wet floors.
Key Stakeholders
5.13.1 It is recognised that the cleanliness of the Trust is the responsibility of various stakeholders.
5.13.2 The Domestic Services department work closely with the following to ensure a cohesive approach to cleanliness is provided:
Patient representation: assist in auditing;
Ward Sisters: assist in review of cleaning schedules, monitor cleaning standards locally with Domestic Supervisors;
Infection Prevention: assist in the development and implementation of local standard precaution protocols and procedures following any outbreak of infection.
EFM Business Development Unit: monitoring and reporting cleaning standards.
Reporting Cleanliness Issues
5.14.1 The reporting of cleanliness issues is vital for the continual improvement of cleaning standards.
5.14.2 Patients and visitors are encouraged to report problems or concerns via notices displayed in toilet areas.
5.14.3 Domestic staff have a mechanism in place to report all issues to their immediate supervisor, manager or ward sister.
5.14.4 Supervisory teams currently use pagers to ensure a speedy response to spillages and other requests.
5.14.5 Domestic assistance is available 24/7 via following the site specific processes (please see appendix 3).
Tagging System for Equipment Cleanliness
5.15.1 A tagging system is used within the Trust to identify when equipment (such as commodes, drip stands, nursing equipment etc.) and bed spaces have been cleaned.

5.15.2 A tagging system is also used to identify when an item of patient equipment has been decontaminated prior to its return to the Medical Equipment Library or BME for repair. All the tags must be filled in completely after every clean has been completed in accordance with the Trust Decontamination Policy.
Breaches, risk events, serious incidents etc

5.16.1 All breaches of this policy must be reported to the Domestic Services Management team. All matters will then be investigated and remedial action taken to rectify the issues. Any further training requirements or necessary disciplinary action will be taken in accordance with Trust Policy.

5.16.2 All risk events or serious incidents must be reported to either a Domestic Supervisor of the Domestic Services Manager. These will be escalated via the Incident reporting system and the H&S Manager informed. An investigation will be conducted as per Trust Policy.
NHS Specification for Cleanliness Audits (49 elements)

5.17.1 The Trust operates a robust monitoring system based on the National Standards of Cleanliness (a framework in which to measure performance outcomes), this provides a comparative framework within which hospitals can assess “technical” cleanliness along with the option for peer review.

5.17.2 All areas are monitored by Domestic Supervisors and Ward Sisters/Departmental Managers in accordance with the national auditing tool and an action plan is produced to correct any areas falling below the required standard of cleanliness. Below is a table explaining the targets and Trust thresholds. If an area falls below the threshold then this will be re-audited as required until it reaches the threshold target and re-audited as set out below:

data.text: 5.17.4 The EFM Business Development Unit also monitor and audit the process of the domestic cleaning service. The cleaning audit results are presented as a Domestic Weekly and Monthly Dashboard and a report submitted to the Patient Experience Group.
Patient Led Assessment of the Care Environment (PLACE)

5.18.1  PLACE assessments are undertaken on an annual basis in accordance with NHSI. The audit includes a wide range of environmental issues including cleanliness and infection prevention. The results of the PLACE assessment are monitored by the Infection Prevention and Control Group.
Patient Surveys

5.19.1  Internal and National patient surveys are carried out within the trust which include cleaning issues. The Domestic Department also carry out Patient Surveys quarterly as part of an internal monitoring tool.
Complaints

5.20.1  Complaints regarding cleanliness issued are investigated by the Domestic Services Manager and necessary corrective actions put in place as required. All complaints are scrutinised by the central complaints team.
Governance Standards
5.21.1  The delivery of the cleaning service has a direct impact to the compliance of the Care Quality Commission (CQC) and NHS England standards as listed below:

Regulation  - The intention of this regulation is to make sure that the premises and equipment utilised to deliver care and treatment are clean, suitable for the intended purpose, maintained, stored securely, used properly and where required, appropriately located. Premises and equipment must maintain standards of hygiene appropriate for the purposes for which they are being used in clinical and non-clinical areas and ensure that the premises and equipment meet the national specification for cleanliness.
Training Requirements

All staff with responsibility for cleaning must be adequately trained and made aware of the importance of high standards of cleanliness, this is essential for both service excellence and staff safety. Training programmes are systematically applied and include both “classroom” and “on-the-job” training; and refresher training should be routinely provided as and when appropriate. Refresher training would be given where a specific area does not maintain the expected standard of cleanliness. The training Centre of Excellence provides standards of training requirements in line with BICs. Monthly observations are undertaken by Domestic Supervisors to ensure that staff continue to adhere to the correct standards and practices.

All  Domestic  staff  complete  a  comprehensive  local  induction  programme  that incorporates classroom based training on subjects such as COSHH, Colour Coding, PPE  Infection  prevention  and  Health  and  Safety  as  well  as  the  National Specification of Cleanliness.
It is important to ensure that staff responsible for cleanliness has the ability and support to do a good job through:

On-the-job support;
Customer service training;
Supervisory, managerial and leadership development training;

What are you proposing to change?

This is a formal review of the Cleaning Policy to align policies across the trust. This policy has also been transferred to the MSE template. There are changes in the scope of the document to include general and reactive cleaning activities undertaken by Estates, Nursing and Catering Staff. The area risk categories have been included. Changes to the roles and responsibilities have been included to highlight structure changes. Information has been included in the Procedure of Cleaning regarding mattresses. Information has been updated regarding cleaning service availability out of hours under Cleaning schedules Responsibilities for cleaning bodily fluids has been updated to include the decontamination process and include trained domestic staff as responsible for non-clinical areas Public areas has been updated to include the team responsible for cleaning external areas and include Grounds & Gardens Team for clearing pathways. Equipment Cleanliness has been updated to include all equipment.
Why are you making this change?
These changes are required in order to ensure the document is

reflective of the current services provided across the group, ensure the services and areas provided are within scope and all staff are aware of their responsibilities to the policy. Services provided alongside cleaning services are identified within the policy, such as mattress services and catering services as this will have an impact on the service delivery, and out of hours services. These changes have also been made to ensure that the standards of cleanliness and the correct CQC regulations are maintained.
Who benefits from this change and how?

The policy is mainly providing benefit to Domestic Staff and staff with responsibility for cleaning, such as catering and nursing staff across the group. The policy clearly outlines the aims and objectives for staff groups involved with hospital cleanliness.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.

No- there is no negative impact sustained from these changes. The changes are highlighting responsibility changes due to staff structures, and includes further details regarding the standards for hospital cleanliness.
